<NEW>

As he wen=
t over towards the..  Rising architecture in the region, WHEELIE simply had=
 nowhere else to go.  Finding his way out of the communications blockade wo=
uld take too long, and even then the Maximals going into it would be scatte=
red.  Such a signal could easily be faked by anyone with commuincations gea=
r, and whatever it was was almost guaranteed to be a decoy or a trap, not a=
 dropped Autobot.  Such things were a tactic as old as communications warfa=
re existed.

But he simply had nothing else to go on.  For the moment, as h=
e zoomed along the road slowly, the dust and mud from the jungle and the cl=
earing foilage still obscuring him somewhat as he went along the tracks, he=
 had no other leads.  HE could not pick up anything on sensors, he was not =
a good enough technician to try and backtrack along the signal or try and b=
ypass it, adnh the foliage of the jungle was far too thick for him to attem=
pt any sort of scans regardless.

So, he could not do anything but drive to=
wards it, cautiously as he could, keeping his scanners set to passive and r=
unning along primarily on visual and auditory scanners.

At this point, he =
did not know whether the approaching structure was something made by the na=
tives of thi splanet in time, or would be something of clearly alien manufa=
cture.

Upon feeling the..  Ghosts upon hi ssensors, Wheelie stayed quiet. =
 He did not know what they were, but he felt the chill upon ihs spark regar=
dless.  Yet he could not see them, out of the corner of his optics or on an=
y sort of sensor.  Yet there was something there, if even nothing more than=
 his own unease.

At the very least, hopefully there would be SOMETHING ahe=
ad in th structure to give him a goal..  Or, otehrwise if he was being purs=
ued, to give him a bit of cover he could use to shield himself if eh came u=
nder attack!

ort to remain unnoticed as he was previously.
